triplet_2188_question.question: What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_2188_question.text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?
triplet_2188_question.displayed_text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

triplet_2188_rating.question: What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_2188_rating.text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of comments:

  • Broad sentiment: Tipping culture feels overextended, coercive, and confusing. Many want employers to pay a living wage so workers don’t rely on tips, with tips becoming optional or eliminated altogether.

  • Where tipping is appropriate: Strong support for reserving tipping for sit-down, service-heavy experiences and for above-and-beyond service. Many object to prompts for pickups, drive-thru, coffee counters, or self-service.

  • Payment models preferred:

  • Pay a living wage or at least the full minimum wage to tipped workers; end sub-minimum wages.
  • Either eliminate tipping and raise prices or replace it with a built-in service charge (often suggested around 10%), with optional tipping for exceptional service.

  • If tipping remains, it should be post-service, voluntary, and merit-based.

  • Frustrations and concerns:

  • “Tipflation” and social pressure from tablet prompts, especially pre-service; desire for an easy, visible “no tip” option.
  • Feeling that tipping lets employers underpay and shifts costs to customers.

  • Unpredictable income for workers and confusion about how much to tip.

  • Minority views and variations:

  • Some consistently tip generously and see it as a valuable incentive for good service.
  • A few favor standardized or even mandatory approaches (fixed-amount tips instead of percentages, or mandatory tips unless wages meet a threshold, and ideas like no taxes on tips or employer matching).

  • A handful would limit tipping strictly to restaurant servers.

  • Values that recur: Fair compensation via wages, clarity and transparency, limiting intrusive asks, aligning tipping with service quality, and reducing pressure on consumers while ensuring workers are treated fairly.

triplet_2188_comparison.question: What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_2188_comparison.text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of comments:

  • Broad sentiment: Tipping culture feels overextended, coercive, and confusing. Many want employers to pay a living wage so workers don’t rely on tips, with tips becoming optional or eliminated altogether.

  • Where tipping is appropriate: Strong support for reserving tipping for sit-down, service-heavy experiences and for above-and-beyond service. Many object to prompts for pickups, drive-thru, coffee counters, or self-service.

  • Payment models preferred:

  • Pay a living wage or at least the full minimum wage to tipped workers; end sub-minimum wages.
  • Either eliminate tipping and raise prices or replace it with a built-in service charge (often suggested around 10%), with optional tipping for exceptional service.

  • If tipping remains, it should be post-service, voluntary, and merit-based.

  • Frustrations and concerns:

  • “Tipflation” and social pressure from tablet prompts, especially pre-service; desire for an easy, visible “no tip” option.
  • Feeling that tipping lets employers underpay and shifts costs to customers.

  • Unpredictable income for workers and confusion about how much to tip.

  • Minority views and variations:

  • Some consistently tip generously and see it as a valuable incentive for good service.
  • A few favor standardized or even mandatory approaches (fixed-amount tips instead of percentages, or mandatory tips unless wages meet a threshold, and ideas like no taxes on tips or employer matching).

  • A handful would limit tipping strictly to restaurant servers.

  • Values that recur: Fair compensation via wages, clarity and transparency, limiting intrusive asks, aligning tipping with service quality, and reducing pressure on consumers while ensuring workers are treated fairly.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments: - General sentiment: Strong dissatisfaction with current tipping culture. Many feel tipping has become over-expected, coercive, and intrusive—especially due to tablet prompts, pre-service requests, and tipping for minimal/zero service (pickup, counter service, coffee). - Employer responsibility: Broad agreement that businesses—not customers—should ensure livable, predictable wages. Many want to abolish the subminimum wage and raise base pay (often citing at least $15/hour) so tips become optional bonuses rather than necessities. - Preferred reforms: - Replace tipping with service-included pricing or a fixed service charge (often around 10%), or fold compensation into menu prices—citing European/Japanese models. - Keep tipping strictly optional and tied to quality of service, given only after service is rendered. - Limit tipping expectations to full-service restaurants; discourage or remove prompts for counter service, pickup, drive-thru, or low-touch transactions. - Improve point-of-sale design: clear “no tip” option, no default pressure, and no pre-service prompts. - Ensure minimum standards: some suggest minimum wages for all tipped workers, no taxes on tips, or employer matching a portion of tips. - A few propose standardizing tipping (e.g., fixed-dollar tips rather than percentages) or making tips mandatory only if wages remain low. - Rationale: Current norms shift labor costs to consumers, create social pressure and guilt, strain budgets, and leave workers with uncertain incomes. Tipping should reward exceptional service, not subsidize base pay. - Minority perspectives: A smaller share defends tipping as a useful incentive and reports always tipping generously; a few support mandatory tips or embedding them in the bill to guarantee worker income. - Common ground: Regardless of stance on tipping’s future, there is strong agreement that workers deserve fair, livable, and predictable compensation, and that any tipping that remains should be voluntary and merit-based.

- Where tipping is appropriate: Strong support for reserving tipping for sit-down, service-heavy experiences and for above-and-beyond service. Many object to prompts for pickups, drive-thru, coffee counters, or self-service.

- Values that recur: Fair compensation via wages, clarity and transparency, limiting intrusive asks, aligning tipping with service quality, and reducing pressure on consumers while ensuring workers are treated fairly.
triplet_2188_comparison.summary_b_text:
Overall summary of the comments:
- General sentiment: Strong dissatisfaction with current tipping culture. Many feel tipping has become over-expected, coercive, and intrusive—especially due to tablet prompts, pre-service requests, and tipping for minimal/zero service (pickup, counter service, coffee).
- Employer responsibility: Broad agreement that businesses—not customers—should ensure livable, predictable wages. Many want to abolish the subminimum wage and raise base pay (often citing at least $15/hour) so tips become optional bonuses rather than necessities.
- Preferred reforms:
  - Replace tipping with service-included pricing or a fixed service charge (often around 10%), or fold compensation into menu prices—citing European/Japanese models.
  - Keep tipping strictly optional and tied to quality of service, given only after service is rendered.
  - Limit tipping expectations to full-service restaurants; discourage or remove prompts for counter service, pickup, drive-thru, or low-touch transactions.
  - Improve point-of-sale design: clear “no tip” option, no default pressure, and no pre-service prompts.
  - Ensure minimum standards: some suggest minimum wages for all tipped workers, no taxes on tips, or employer matching a portion of tips.
  - A few propose standardizing tipping (e.g., fixed-dollar tips rather than percentages) or making tips mandatory only if wages remain low.
- Rationale: Current norms shift labor costs to consumers, create social pressure and guilt, strain budgets, and leave workers with uncertain incomes. Tipping should reward exceptional service, not subsidize base pay.
- Minority perspectives: A smaller share defends tipping as a useful incentive and reports always tipping generously; a few support mandatory tips or embedding them in the bill to guarantee worker income.
- Common ground: Regardless of stance on tipping’s future, there is strong agreement that workers deserve fair, livable, and predictable compensation, and that any tipping that remains should be voluntary and merit-based.
